content: Conic sections are formed by the intersection of a plane and a cone. there are four main conic sections - circle, parabola, ellipse and hyperbola.

A circle is the set of points in a plane that are equidistant from a given point, called the center. The distance from the center to a point in the circle is called the radius. Twice the radius is known as the diameter.

A parabola is a curve where any point is at an equal distance from:
  a fixed point (the focus), and
  a fixed straight line (the directrix)

An ellipse is the set of all points on a plane whose distance from two fixed points F and G add up to a constant. "F" is a focus, "G" is a focus, and together they are called foci. (pronounced "fo-sigh")

A hyperbola is a curve where the distances of any point from: a fixed point (the focus), and a fixed straight line (the directrix) are always in the same ratio. The hyperbola is an open curve (has no ends).
A non-linear system of equations is a system in which at least one of the variables has an exponent other than 1.
